name: Writing about Literature, Art and Culture
base_name: Writing about Literature, Art and Culture

equiv.name: Advanced First Year Writing: Special Topics

long_desc: This mini or halfsemester course one of two minis students can choose to fulfill their FYW requirement uses artistic, literary, and cultural texts e.g., poetry, short story, lyrics, video clips to introduce students to a variety of academic reading and writing practices that enable students to engage with texts and write about them with complexity and nuance. Within the course, we will discuss texts and evidence from multiple perspectives. We will examine how literary and cultural scholars write about texts defined broadly, how they make claims, provide reasoning, and use textual support to argue for particular ways of seeing cultural objects. Throughout the semester, students will draw upon prior strategies and develop new ones for close reading and for critical analysis in order to produce their own thesisdriven arguments about why texts matter. We will consider and write about the extent to which these reading strategies are relevant for other kinds of reading and analysis by comparing texts from a variety of different disciplinary contexts. Because the course emphasizes authentic stakes and purposes for communicating with academic audiences, students will regularly share their work with their peers in oral and written forms within an interactive and collaborative classroom environment.

custom_fields.goals: After taking 76106, you should be able to write interpretive essays that are compelling, careful, clear, and considerate of your readers. You should be able toUse close reading processes for reading literary textsInterpret text with a framework or theoretical lensWrite clear, readerfriendly, reasonable arguments Employ rhetorical strategies for writing interpretive, thesisdriven academic essays Integrate textual evidence strategically to advance your own interpretive argumentAnalyze model texts to understand the demands of a writing taskDevelop strategies for managing your writing processes Engage in productive peer collaboration for all stages of writing, including planning, drafting, and revising
custom_fields.key_topics: Argument, Critical Analysis, Close Reading, Interpretive methods, Theoretical Lens, Thesis-driven essay, Literature/Art/Culture
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should be able to work comfortably with summary, paraphrase and basic citation methods to support source-based writing; should be familiar with basic argument skills for both reading and writing; should exercise control over language choices and should exercise control over composition processes; should be familiar with a variety of strategies for planning and writing texts.

custom_fields.relevance: 76-106 is one of three First-Year Writing mini (half-semester) courses, along with 76-107 and 76-108. Taking two out of these three minis is one of the course options that students can choose to fulfill their First-Year Writing requirement. The other option is to take a full-semester course, normally 76-101. If you like the idea of a fresh start in the middle of the semester, taking two mini courses might be a good option for you. The minis offer students the opportunity to focus upon strategies for particular types of communication situations and target genres. By taking two minis, you will gain exposure to more than one kind of writing: arts & humanities-based (76-106), technical (76-107), and professional (76-108). You will also learn ways of adapting to new and different communication situations. Some students report a more dynamic structure and pace driven by the break at mid-semester.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: 1:1 conferences with faculty about your writing
